												My favorite arcade racing game in 18 years! Super recommended!(Since F-Zero X and R4: Ridge Racer Type 4)My initial review had ended there already, but since I'm a little shocked about all the negative reviews and comments about this game, I decided to write some more...TMT is time trial based racing at its very best. The controls are responsive and nuanced, the track designs are outstanding, and there is a lot of content and variety, both online and offline. The fine developers at Nadeo have crafted a unique game with an abundance of imaginative features and ideas. It really succeeds to fill a void, that so many rather standardized modern racing games have left behind.The game can be quite hard, especially the Rollercoatser Lagoon setting, and to feel some frustration is part of what Trackmania is about. Still, Nadeo has achieved a balanced progression in the campaign mode, which always gives you enough rewards and incentives to continue. I'm usually not too much into super challenging games, but TMT is absolutely addicting.And the presentation of TMT is fantastic. A great color scheme evoking memories of 90's arcade racing, some of the coolest original cars and environments in a long time, and very nice signage and typography. While the later is not quite on the level of what Designers Republic did for the WipEout series, it does come pretty close sometimes. Many complaints here on Steam are targeted at the limited customization options compared to previous Trackmania games, but I find it hard to understand, why anyone would want to change any of those assets. The game achieves an amazing coherent art style, which is just a pure joy to experience.TMT is more focused and polished than any Trackmania game before, making it my favorite Trackmania experience by far. I'm very inclined to say that this is one of the best arcade racers of all time!

												This game is the successor to the TM2 series, which I never personally played. The graphics are a godsend, and it's certainly a nice upgrade from TMU which I play(ed) quite a lot. There is a nice long single-player campaign that should be fun to grind through, however I dislike how you have to play through every single environment so you can start on the next set of maps. For instance, Canyon is my favourite environment, and I really don't like any of the other maps, but I have to play through all of them so I can move onto the next set of Canyon maps.There isn't a lot happening in the way of multiplayer too...the servers are now hosted my Nadeo, so there's less customisability to them. I doubt the multiplayer/eSports scene will ever get as big as it did for TMU or TM2 because of the difficulty in setting the matches up, and we probably won't see larger scale servers like 'The Loveshack' run by FAB team any time soon.Controls are easy enough to pick up, but I'd definitely recommend using a controller as it makes everything 10x easier in my opinion.I haven't tried the local multiplayer yet, but the Double Driver mode sounds fun, and having some mates over to try out the 4-player splitscreen would be awesome. I'll probably try and find some friends first and then update this review with my thoughts.To be honest, I'd recommend buying this game in a sale, as it's definitely got replayability and an enjoyment factor. I don't think it's worth £30 though, as the lack of severs and apparently small user-base let it down a bit. Anything under £20 and I'd say 'get it now'.But yeah, let's go with a solid 7/10.

												EDIT: Most of the problems mentioned in my original review still remain, but the more i played of Trackmania Turbo, the more i started to like it for what it is. It's a much different game than the old Trackmania games, but i realized that that was not what they intended. I can now reccomend this game, but i think i would still wait for a discount!ORIGINAL REVIEW:I've played countless hours of Trackmania United Forever, and was very excited for Trackmania Turbo to come out. I started the singleplayer campain and really enjoyed the 4 different environments and the basic racing. Just as i expected from a Trackmania. After around four hours i decided to try out all the other things a Trackmania has to offer, like the Trackbuilder, online multiplayer and the car customization. And i was so dissapointed.This game is lacking so many multiplayer features compared to previous games, it's s quite shocking. There are no dedicated servers, no leaderboards, the UI is a big mess.. And then the Trackbuilder.. It becomes so obvious that this game is a console port. Everything is optimized for a controller, doing basic trackbuilding becomes a pain. You want to name the track you just created? You're out of luck, it just gets a number as the name and you have no way of changing that. Want to share that track? That is also a big mess with some kind of confusing challenges and no way of just realeasing the track on its own.You want to paint your car in some funny or creative way? Nah, they just deleted that feature, but you can now choose between some paintjobs that you can unlock by doing the campaign, yay.The basic gameplay is fine, but with all the missing features and this game beeing an obvious console port, i just can't reccommend it in its current state. I regret playing more than 2 hours before realizing the mess that this game is, because i would love to refund it and wait with the purchase until they change the things i mentioned above. And i would advise you to do the same. If you have never played a Trackmania, buy ANY other but this one, they are all fantastic.

												If you're into single player racing, TM:T is a very good purchase. If not, TMUF or TM2 is definitely the better choice.That said, it has online leaderboards with no need to specifically attempt an official time; every try counts. The single player campaign is lengthy and a lot of fun, and the game looks good and runs well. The difficulty curve in the campaign is generally good. Some of the tracks feel kind of cheap, though, because some of the obstacles have a tendency to send your car spiraling to its doom with no apparent reason. Also, the Lagoon environment has sandy beaches that are a real pain to drive on, and wooden loops where you have little to no control. An analogue controller helps alleviate these pains a bit, though. The price tag is a bit high for a single player racer, but it's really nice for what it is. As a Trackmania game, it's very stripped down, which seems to cause of a lot of anger in TM veterans.*edit* Regarding my 0.9 hours played: I own the game on Uplay and have finished the single player campaign.

												This game is the perfect racing game for those who just want to get wheels on the track and times on the board. Sure, the customization of your own server, or car, horn, avatar, etc, isnt there. What is here is a far more streamlined racing experience, where you dont have to worry about not having the files that the server uses, where having a server of your own is much easier, and having fun with friends comes much more quickly. Trackbuilder is great, sometimes just diving into what the computer can make is fun, sometimes you want to have total control over your map, down to the smallest detail. Despite what the stalwart racers would claim, its not that much different from TM2's trackbuilder. Overall its a fun game for those who desire speed and simplicity, vs complexity and precision.

But for now, the game is very good, and I think it would've been much worse if it hadn't been delayed.Update: After trying to come back to the game, the UPlay system seems to not want to let me play the game anymore. I've tried to enter my code that it gives me, reinstall the game, restart steam, restart pc, and nothing is working. Therefore, I'm turning my review to negative as the game only ever gave me 4-5 hours of gameplay and the game doesn't work. I have requested my refund, and I'm sorry to say this game is not very good. It had such potential, but is not up to the standards I expected for a delayed release date.
